author: Harper Lee
description: Refugees and border guards in the Białowieża Forest. Scenes of violence play out behind a thick cover of trees, in a remote corner of Poland
review: A gripping, heart-wrenching, and wholly remarkable tale of coming-of-age in a South poisoned by virulent prejudice.

author: George Orwell
description: Two vastly different books — one a picaresque tale, the other a dystopian meditation — both recount a transition from human to animal or from animal to human.
review: A dystopian social science fiction novel and cautionary tale about the dangers of totalitarianism.

author: Jane Austen
description: Catch a young swallow. Roast her in honey. Eat her up. Then you will understand all languages. » In his 1996 co-authored book, The art and science of language learning, Swedish polyglot Erik Gunnemark joked that people could use this recipe, which he’d found in an old book of black magic, to avoid the hard work of learning a new language.
review: A romantic novel of manners that depicts the British Regency era's social milieu.

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
description: You could tell the story of modernity in Europe through its hotels. There’s surely not a single topic or debate that wasn’t discussed over their polished wooden tables and chrome bars, or in the snug armchairs of their lobbies and the deckchairs of their beachside terraces.
review: A critical and scathing tale of the American Dream in the 1920s.

author: J.D. Salinger
description: We had a neighbour in Cornwall who had retired years earlier from the Merchant Navy. On rainy afternoons I would often go to Claude’s house; he and his wife Lillian had Indonesian nutcracker figures and plates on walls depicting warm bays and mountains that were exotic to my ten-yearold self.
review: A novel about teenage rebellion and angst in the post-war era.

author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: First there is the testimony of a Bauhaus student that every time he encountered Mies approaching in a corridor, he thought he was seeing two people; only from up close did they merge into the single Mies.
review: A fantastical journey through Middle-earth that introduces the world of Tolkien's legendarium.

bookName: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
description: n Amsterdam, there’s a street named after Raphael Lemkin. It’s in the southeast, historically a mostly Surinamese neighborhood. Once, walking through, I saw two teenage kids playing football on a corner.
review: The beginning of an epic tale of magic, friendship, and adventure.

author: Dan Brown
description: Natalia Ginzburg (1916-1991) needs very few words to paint very rich and lively characters. The novella Valentino (1957) needs less than one hundred pages to build their entire world.
review: A fast-paced thriller that combines art, religion, and conspiracy.
